instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-2926: What is 820-2926? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green / Orange Light, Fan spin, No Chime & No display.
threads.message:
I don't even know where to start at this moment anymore, I've been working on this device most of my day and It just doesn't want to work.

[B]Story:[/B]
Customer handed me his macbook. Told me he got the motherboard replaced at company *X* for $700 a year ago, but now it keeps rebooting, is unstable or doesn't want to power up at times. He checked and said there was lots of corrosion but company *X* told him it was his fault and not theirs.

After opening up the macbook and inspecting the motherboard it looked like absolutely trash underneath the microscope. Flux everywhere and it just looks like all the parts were resolderd atleast once. On every single part of the board where the pads would usually be nostuff there is solder now, indicating someone went past it with his iron.
They also used this annoying thick flux which is just surrounding most of the chips, its not solid but its definitely hard to remove at room temperature, it also makes it hard for me to probe points.
After some good inspection the most screwed up part was around the SMC, quite the bit of corrosion. I cleaned most of the corrosion up with 99.9% 2-Propanol and checked but it didn't solve the issues (When will it ever be simple? haha), the system was still acting rather oddly and most of the time wouldn't even power on..
I expected corrosion underneath the SMC, since its the logical explanation why power management is acting weird. I de-soldered the SMC and placed on a new one. Well this is where the bigger issues started, now the system always powers on.. But there is no Chime and No display.

Often the system stays on for about 8 seconds before it shuts down completely, if you quickly reconnect the charger it will power on again and stay on (But still no Chime and display).

VCore is 1.15V and the CPU gets warm, if I power it on without any ram modules installed the system would start beeping, indicating an issue with ram.

I then replaced the SMC chip with another new one (You never really know what kind of crap china sends you), however the issue stayed exactly the same.

I also checked the data going in to the SPI Chip (<CHIP>U6100</CHIP>), the CLK is there and it seems like data is both going IN&OUT. The clock and data looks pretty odd compared to a working <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, in the start there is about 1-2 seconds of 0.5 second long high/low pulses before actual data is being sent. Also sometimes these long pulses happen while also data is going over it.
It might not be relatable to this issue, though.

[B]Short Version:[/B]

Macbook had issues with booting at times, very unstable. Corrosion on the board and just a lot of flux everywhere from someone else. Cleaned corrosion and decided to replace SMC chip due lots of corrosion around that area. After new SMC the light on the charger shows, the fan spins but there is no Chime and no Display or backlight. Replaced with another SMC chip (from the same batch), same issues.
CPU VCore is 1.15V, CPU gets warm and when booted up without RAM memory it will beep.
System often shuts down after about 8 seconds, but when booted up for the second time in a very short period it will stay on.
Checked <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> (SPI Chip's clock and data, looked a bit off compared to a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. I however don't have another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> to compare.

All major power lines are up as far as I checked

I got a digital oscilloscope, its not state of the art technology but good enough to see clocks and data over non-high speed chips. If you want me to check some part with the oscilloscope I can post screenshots of its output.

[B]Questions:[/B]

- Where to look? What could be causing this issue?
- Might the second SMC also be bad? Is it worth a fair try to replace it a 3rd time but with a totally different seller's stock?
- Is it possible I toasted the chipset (<CHIP>U1800</CHIP>) while soldering the SMC back on? (I doubt it, I didn't use /insane/ temperatures. I can't exclude it either though..)

Thanks in advance, let me know if there are any questions.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green / Orange Light, Fan spin, No Chime & No display.
threads.message: You need to use SMC from an identical donor board because they have firmware. Not a new one or some China random reballed one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green / Orange Light, Fan spin, No Chime & No display.
threads.message:
Oh my, what a noob mistake.
Only if I'd just asked it earlier I could've been hanging on the couch instead haha

Just to be sure, if I get the SMC from a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2926</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> donor board it should work? If not I'll just get a BGA stencil for the SMC and I'll reball the original SMC I de-soldered.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green / Orange Light, Fan spin, No Chime & No display.
threads.message: Yes, you will need a stencil to reball it regardless. Unless you want to reball it by hand.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green / Orange Light, Fan spin, No Chime & No display.
threads.message:
Oh yeah obviously, 3AM is really getting to me.

Thanks for your help again, sorry for having to listen to my dumb questions!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green / Orange Light, Fan spin, No Chime & No display.
threads.message:
Finally had time to solder on a SMC from a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> donor board but it does not POST.

Fan stays on and gets louder the longer it stays on, the CPU gets warm.

I'll check tomorrow why it doesn't complete its POST, this behaviour seems to match the issue the customer described. Although I can not be sure if this is actually an issue that was there when it got to me or if the replacement SMC is still screwing up. (I have no idea if the SMC can prevent the system from completing POST but still getting into an S0 state)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green / Orange Light, Fan spin, No Chime & No display.
threads.message: Vcore voltage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green / Orange Light, Fan spin, No Chime & No display.
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is 0.85V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green / Orange Light, Fan spin, No Chime & No display.
threads.message: That seems ok it was 1.15V before and that is not cool, is a USB mouse lighting up now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green / Orange Light, Fan spin, No Chime & No display.
threads.message:
Actually I've been mistaken, the system does POST! I had the assumption the chime would sound from both speakers, however it only does from the speaker next to the wireless module. My bad
(And since it posts the USB mouse indeed did light up)

It runs unbearably slow though. I ran AHT and it came back with (4SNS/1/40000000: VD0R-19.314)

Which if I'm correctly indicates a sensor issue (4SNS), with the DC voltage sensor. I think the 19.314 number might be a voltage, but even without the charger plugged in this number stays above 19V so its not likely <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>. When it runs off the battery its slightly lower though (3 tests, ~19.01-19.19 on battery, 2 tests >19.3 on charger). Maybe its noting like a voltage though and I'm just speculating too much

Since the SMC (If I recall correctly) processes the sensor information, is it still perfectly possible I didn't solder the SMC back on properly or the replacement SMC is damaged?

Thanks again for the support

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green / Orange Light, Fan spin, No Chime & No display.
threads.message: As been discussed many times before <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> and resistors around it. Also run the proper EFI ASD test, not this built in garbage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green / Orange Light, Fan spin, No Chime & No display.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PBUS_S0_VSENSE</SIGNAL> is 12.55V and <SIGNAL>SMC_PBUS_VSENSE</SIGNAL> is 2.07V, <RESISTOR>R5301</RESISTOR>-<RESISTOR>R5304</RESISTOR> all within their 1%. Nothing wrong with the <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> circuit as far as I'm aware

I'll run ASD in a moment (First time I heard of that tool, thanks), if it doesn't give me any more clarity I'll reball the SMC in case I may have messed that up.

Will report back later today

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green / Orange Light, Fan spin, No Chime & No display.
threads.message:
EFI ASD came back with all the sensors passed except VD0R (DC in Rail 0)

"Sensor is reading above the high limit"

Which sounds very odd to me, its not shorted with another power line or sensor because I would've seen that when I probed <SIGNAL>SMC_PBUS_VSENSE</SIGNAL>.
Can you confirm 2.07V is a normal value for <SIGNAL>SMC_PBUS_VSENSE</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green / Orange Light, Fan spin, No Chime & No display.
threads.message: Are you using a 60W charger? If you use a 85W one it will report this error. You can also check the hardware profile in ASD and all sensor values are listed there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green / Orange Light, Fan spin, No Chime & No display.
threads.message:
I was using a 85W charger, I had no idea this would cause the test to fail.
The test comes back with failed on the DC in voltage too with a 60W charger and without charger at all

The value measured is between 19.1-19.4V

I do have another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> laying around but I'd have to take it apart from the laptop, I'll see if I can check what <SIGNAL>SMC_PBUS_VSENSE</SIGNAL> measures from there

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green / Orange Light, Fan spin, No Chime & No display.
threads.message: Measure voltage on <CAPACITOR>C5304</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C5314</CAPACITOR>. Once powered on and once shut down but with AC plugged in.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green / Orange Light, Fan spin, No Chime & No display.
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C5304</CAPACITOR> powered on 2.07V
<CAPACITOR>C5314</CAPACITOR> powered on 2.79V

<CAPACITOR>C5304</CAPACITOR> powered off 0.00V
<CAPACITOR>C5314</CAPACITOR> powered off 2.82V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green / Orange Light, Fan spin, No Chime & No display.
threads.message:
Some additional measurements

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>:16.85V
<SIGNAL>DCIN_S5_VSENSE</SIGNAL>: 16.84V

<RESISTOR>R5311</RESISTOR>: 99.8k Ohm [Should be 100kOhm]
<RESISTOR>R5312</RESISTOR>: 100k Ohm [Should be 100kOhm]
<RESISTOR>R5313</RESISTOR>: 27.2kOhm [Should be 27.4kOhm]
<RESISTOR>R5314</RESISTOR>: 5.46kOhm [Should be 5.49kOhm]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green / Orange Light, Fan spin, No Chime & No display.
threads.message: If you continue the ASD after the error is this the only sensor that fails? 2.8V after the resistor divider is correct for about 16V of DCIN voltage. What is ASD reporting for VD0r in the hardware profile?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green / Orange Light, Fan spin, No Chime & No display.
threads.message:
Yes, this is the only sensor thats failing, the other sensors come back without any errors and with appropriate values

It currently reports that VD0R is 19.105V with the 60W adapter

Is it worth a try to remove <RESISTOR>R5313</RESISTOR>? The low-limit is set to 0V so it should report back fine with that resistor removed. If the SMC still reads a high value but there is no voltage on <SIGNAL>SMC_DCIN_VSENSE</SIGNAL> its to be sure the SMC is malfuncioning

EDIT:
One thing in the Hardware Profile what stood out to me is that on "ACAdapterPort" it reports the adapter-voltage as 19.485V, its probably because of the faulty VD0R readout?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green / Orange Light, Fan spin, No Chime & No display.
threads.message:
I Removed <RESISTOR>R5313</RESISTOR> and verified <SIGNAL>SMC_DCIN_VSENSE</SIGNAL> is 0V, the sensor still reads out a too high voltage of 19.105V

SMC is broken, lets buy a new one. Will report back when I have it soldered on
